message_1: What is the enthalpy of combustion of methane gas (CH4) at standard conditions (298 K and 1 atm) if the heat of formation of methane is -74.9 kJ/mol and the products of combustion are carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O)? Calculate the enthalpy of combustion in both kJ/mol and kJ/g.
message_2:
To calculate the enthalpy of combustion of methane, we need to use the following equation:

ΔH_combustion = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

where ΔH_combustion is the enthalpy of combustion, ΔH_f(products) is the sum of the heats of formation of the products, and ΔH_f(reactants) is the sum of the heats of formation of the reactants.

The balanced equation for the combustion of methane is:

CH4(g) + 2 O2(g) → CO2(g) + 2 H2O(g)

The heat of formation of methane (CH4) is given as -74.9 kJ/mol. We also need the heats of formation for carbon dioxide (CO2) and water (H2O). The standard heat of formation for CO2(g) is -393.5 kJ/mol, and for H2O(g) is -241.8 kJ/mol.

Now we can calculate the enthalpy of combustion:

ΔH_combustion = [1 × (-393.5 kJ/mol) + 2 × (-241.8 kJ/mol)] - [1 × (-74.9 kJ/mol)]

ΔH_combustion = (-393.5 - 2 × 241.8 + 74.9) kJ/mol

ΔH_combustion = (-393.5 - 483.6 + 74.9) kJ/mol

ΔH_combustion = -802.2 kJ/mol

Now, we need to convert the enthalpy of combustion to kJ/g. The molar mass of methane (CH4) is 12.01 g/mol (C) + 4 × 1.01 g/mol (H) = 16.04 g/mol.

Enthalpy of combustion in kJ/g:

ΔH_combustion = -802.2 kJ/mol ÷ 16.04 g/mol

ΔH_combustion = -50.0 kJ/g

So, the enthalpy of combustion of methane gas at standard conditions is -802.2 kJ/mol and -50.0 kJ/g.
